update.description:
Issue #402

First pull request related to the `undo` feature described in [this](#!/osrf/gazebo_design/src/326dbc5e7f6c283c5d5b39f767287afbf2cf6d60/undo/undo.md?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default) design document.

Undoable user commands for now are those which move models during simulation: translate, rotate, snap, align. They only work for models for now, but once pull request #1920 is merged it should work for lights too.

# Video

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GSkHaZpM1Ro

# Message passing 

## Registering new user commands

1. When a user executes a command, the class which executed the command from the gui side emits a `UserCmd` message.

2. `physics::UserCmdManager` registers the command and sends a message for the gui with the complete stats for all registered commands.

3. The gui updates itself based on the commands.

![undo10.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/1844619545-undo10.png)

## Requesting to undo / redo

1. `gui::UserCmdHistory` sends a `UndoRedo` message with the user request to undo / redo a command

2. `physics::UserCmdManager` executes the request and sends updated `USerCmdStats`

3. `gui::UserCmdHistory` updates itself based on the new stats

![undo20.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/245938902-undo20.png)
update.title: Undo user motion commands during simulation

content.raw: Found the source of the problem, there was a mistake on the equal operator for WorldState, fixed in d8b3ea4. Undo moving lights should be working now. We really need to add more tests for the states.
content.html: Found the source of the problem, there was a mistake on the equal operator for WorldState, fixed in d8b3ea4. Undo moving lights should be working now. We really need to add more tests for the states.

content.raw:
do we want to unboost?

~~~
while (!this->dataPtr->undoCmds.empty() && this->dataPtr->undoCmds.back() != cmd)
~~~

or back to old school c++98 for loop?
content.html:
do we want to unboost?

while (!this->dataPtr->undoCmds.empty() && this->dataPtr->undoCmds.back() != cmd)

or back to old school c++98 for loop?

content.raw: I've been thinking more about this and it probably makes more sense to go with @iche033 's first suggestion of generating incremental unsigned int IDs on the server. If we need a way to identify clients later we can always add that to the message. Sounds good?
content.html: I've been thinking more about this and it probably makes more sense to go with @iche033 's first suggestion of generating incremental unsigned int IDs on the server. If we need a way to identify clients later we can always add that to the message. Sounds good?

content.html:
How about using an embedded message instead, something like:

message UserCmdId
{
  Enum Type
  {
    SNAP = 1;
    TRANSLATE = 2;
    ...
  }

  required Type type;
  required string name;
}

pull_request.title: Undo user motion commands during simulation

update.description:
First pull request related to the `undo` feature described in [this](#!/osrf/gazebo_design/src/326dbc5e7f6c283c5d5b39f767287afbf2cf6d60/undo/undo.md?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default) design document.

Undoable user commands for now are those which move models during simulation: translate, rotate, snap, align. They only work for models for now, but once pull request #1920 is merged it should work for lights too.

# Video

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GSkHaZpM1Ro

# Message passing 

## Registering new user commands

1. When a user executes a command, the class which executed the command from the gui side emits a `UserCmd` message.

2. `physics::UserCmdManager` registers the command and sends a message for the gui with the complete stats for all registered commands.

3. The gui updates itself based on the commands.

![undo10.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/1844619545-undo10.png)

## Requesting to undo / redo

1. `gui::UserCmdHistory` sends a `UndoRedo` message with the user request to undo / redo a command

2. `physics::UserCmdManager` executes the request and sends updated `USerCmdStats`

3. `gui::UserCmdHistory` updates itself based on the new stats

![undo20.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/245938902-undo20.png)

content.raw: humm inside physics, only the `PresetManager` has `GAZEBO_VISIBLE`, the rest all seem to be `GZ_PHYSICS_VISIBLE`. I actually don't know what these are for...
content.html: humm inside physics, only the PresetManager has GAZEBO_VISIBLE, the rest all seem to be GZ_PHYSICS_VISIBLE. I actually don't know what these are for...

update.description:
First pull request related to the `undo` feature described in [this](#!/osrf/gazebo_design/src/326dbc5e7f6c283c5d5b39f767287afbf2cf6d60/undo/undo.md?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default) design document.

Undoable user commands for now are those which move models during simulation: translate, rotate, snap, align. They only work for models for now, but once pull request #1920 is merged it should work for lights too.

# Video

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GSkHaZpM1Ro

# Message passing 

## Registering new user commands

1. When a user executes a command, the class which executed the command from the gui side emits a `UserCmd` message.

2. `physics::UserCmdManager` registers the command and sends a message for the gui with the complete stats for all registered commands.

3. The gui updates itself based on the commands.

![undo10.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/1844619545-undo10.png)

## Requesting to undo / redo

content.raw: ah ok that makes sense, maybe we should just keep it as it is for now. Note that there still could be conflicts between ids for the corner case where two clients move the model at the exact same time
content.html: ah ok that makes sense, maybe we should just keep it as it is for now. Note that there still could be conflicts between ids for the corner case where two clients move the model at the exact same time

content.raw: Oh also I should note that originally I was thinking of having a way to figure out which client the command came from, that's probably one of the reasons I'm generating the id in the client.
content.html: Oh also I should note that originally I was thinking of having a way to figure out which client the command came from, that's probably one of the reasons I'm generating the id in the client.
